Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: S^2 Lab: Educational Platform and Resource for Smartphone Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although the smartphone market has grown rapidly in recent years, education remains mostly in the realm of traditional computer designs, even when it comes to security. One of the crucial factors hindering the adoption of smartphone security in the educational domain is the lack of appropriate platform and educational resources. One option is to use an emulator but emulators have no good support for Bluetooth, USB, peripherals, network connected state, battery charge level, and AC charging state; many of which could be integral components of lab exercises. The goal of this project is to develop a smartphone security education framework and to transition to education some of the emerging research areas related to security issues in the smartphone domain.

The project will develop a smartphone security education platform; develop sample educational resources (labs) that can be supported by the platform; and evaluate the efficacy of the developed platform and resources in promoting experiential learning in the domain of smartphone security education. The proposed platform will be a hardware-software integrated system that will enable students to remotely connect to the platform, choose a smartphone security lab exercise supported by the platform and learn by performing the lab activities on real smartphone devices. This project will enable other institutions of higher education to utilize the platform and resources for smartphone security education. The project outcomes will be disseminated via the NSF-funded SEED labs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed a unique platform of hardware-software integrated system dubbed S2 Lab that enables students to remotely connect to the collection of real Android devices, choose an Android security lab exercise supported by the platform and learn by performing the lab activities on the devices . The S2 lab environment overcomes several limitations of the traditional emulator based or virtual machine based approach of Android security education such as the inability to explore the security issues of the peripheral devices and sensors.

The S2 Lab platform consists of the following elements:

●    The S2 Lab Server is the gateway between users and the Android devices, hosted on Amazon Web Services. The server opens a web socket that listens for any request over HTTPS, and then provides the user a list of devices to choose from and the ability to load a lab chosen by the user to a set of Android devices. The S2 Lab server is the bridge between users and the S2 Lab Controller.

●    The S2 Lab Controller is an application that controls the Android devices, to provide accessibility and communication between the Android devices and S2 Lab server. The S2 Lab controller allows for remotely delivering new Android images or applications from the server to an Android device and reconfigure the Android devices with the new image or the application.  The S2 Lab controller bridges the gap between the S2 Lab server and Android devices.

●    The front-end website is where users can log in and perform application configuration tasks, mainly loading a lab to the devices and completing those labs. This front end provides an interface for S2 Lab users to interact and communicate with the Android device farm via the VNC and console. Additional features include a login page, authentication, and a local database.AWS accommodates both the S2 Lab Server and the front end website, deploying the flexibility and scalability that integrates cloud computing into the S2 lab platform.

The cloud supported web based user interface of the S2 Lab platform enables other institutions of higher educations to seamlessly utilize the developed platform for their research and education. The project has provided a valuable experiential learning opportunity to the undergraduate and graduate students of Cal Poly Pomona which is Hispanic Serving Institution.
